Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54436-005 
Transaction Technical Assistance Cluster (C-TRTA) 
December 2021 
 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance for Women's Financing 
Marketplace - Expansion of the Marketplace 
(Subproject 4) (Regional) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This is a redacted version of the document, which excludes information that is subject to 
exceptions to disclosure set forth in ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
I.  THE WOMEN’S FINANCE EXCHANGE  1 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT  1 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster  1 
B.  Subproject Scope  3 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  3 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing  6

APPENDIXES 
1.  Subproject Cost Estimates and Financing Plan (Removed due to confidentiality.)  Error!

2.  LIST OF LINKED DOCUMENTS  8

I.  THE WOMEN’S FINANCE EXCHANGE 
 
1.  The REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s Financing Marketplace1, approved in 
November 2020 is under implementation. It will facilitate and broaden access to finance for 
women and women-owned or women-led micro, small and medium-sized businesses (WMSMEs) 
and communicate ADB’s efforts in this area to encourage more lending to this sector. Many 
financial institutions (FIs) in ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) have not targeted 
women borrowers and do not recognize the untapped commercial potential. 2 They do not provide 
suitable and affordable products for this clientele and/or lack the awareness of the barriers that 
women or women’s businesses3 encounter when trying to access financial services.4 The impacts 
of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic have reinforced the importance of a digital 
economy to change business models and to integrate digital channels into how financial service 
providers or businesses engage with customers. 
 
2.  During this period and post-COVID-19, a dedicated online platform can help support FIs 
and their existing and potential women borrowers. For branding purposes the Women’s Financing 
Marketplace was renamed to the Women’s Finance Exchange (the “WFX”) in August 2021. The 
WFX will be innovative in its work and take a digital and more agile approach for interaction and 
engagement. Amongst a number of activities, it is expected that the WFX will aggregate and 
disseminate products on gender financing within ADB and to the broader external audience and 
support the identification of cutting-edge technologies for FIs to achieve operational efficiencies, 
reach and scale, and/or develop new products to digitize business models, such as alternative 
credit scoring models, mobile technology, cloud technology, and online delivery channels. Such 
activities are being piloted in Papua New Guinea (PNG) first. In addition, capacity is being 
strengthened for FIs to promote gender responsive financial service delivery and women’s 
businesses to improve viability, as needed, through a range of digital toolkits, webinars and online 
support.  Linkages to other programs and initiatives on enabling access to finance for women, 
internal and external to ADB5 are being established and a community platform to attract other co-
financiers, including potential TA funding providers, is also being created.  
 
3.  The TA cluster is envisaged to have 4 Subprojects: (i) design, set up and maintenance of 
the marketplace, (ii) innovation and technologies, (iii) capacity building, and (iv) expansion of the 
marketplace. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
4.  This is the fourth subproject under the REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s 
Financing Marketplace. The first subproject was approved in November, the second and third 
subproject in December 2021, respectively, and consultants have been recruited. 
 
 
1  The Women’s Financing Marketplace was renamed Women’s Finance Exchange in August 2021 
2  Financial institutions in this context are banks and non-bank financial institutions including microfinance institutions, 
housing finance, and insurance companies, for instance. 
3  Womens’ business in this context means micro-, small- and medium-sized women-owned or women-managed 
businesses. 
4  Barriers are for example limited financial literacy, insufficient credit history, and lack of collateral. 
5  For example, PSFI’s Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program or ADB Ventures and SDCC’s Gender 
and Development initiatives or TechforImpact.

2 
5.  The first year of WFX has been busy, starting operations and rolling-out activities which, 
among others, resulted with the creation of a landing page on ADB.org (adb.org/womens-finance-
exchange) and the official launch with a webinar on 12 August 2021. The launch was attended 
by almost 300 participants from the private and public sector. Further, the WFX started to support 
the first financial institution in PNG to identify new technologies that would support reaching out 
to women-owned or led small- and medium sized enterprises (WSMEs), considering the specific 
context in which the institution is operating. This included research, institutional and market 
assessments, and a hackathon to find suitable fintech solutions. In addition, the first online training 
for WSMEs was piloted in Papua New Guinea. This was especially relevant in the pandemic 
environment and can easily be scaled in other countries. As part of the communication activities 
three case studies, two videos, and four women client interviews were prepared, three webinars 
were organized, and the first newsletter will be published in December. 
 
6.  The WFX also conducted a strategic review, including a branding exercise, with selected 
stakeholders from within ADB as well as external. It has become evident that for branding 
purposes  and  to  successfully  reach  out  and  to  build  a  community,  a  more  agile  working 
environment and set-up was necessary. This includes a platform (website) which provides 
interactive features for engagement, such as member log-in with specific sites, chat functions, 
contact possibilities, SEO-optimized content, mobile friendly and possibility for site analytics. 
 
7.  During the year, WFX attended several webinars, knowledge events and held feedback 
rounds with FIs and women’s businesses. While it is clear that much work needs to be done to 
close the financing gap estimated at $1.7 trillion for WMSMEs6, it is  also evident that the goal 
should not only be improving access to finance for women but also make them more sustainable 
and resilient to climate change and other calamities.  
 
8.  At this year’s UN Climate Change Conference (COP26), global leaders, financiers and 
advocates discussed new action plans and commitments to progress faster on global climate 
goals. It is equally important to consider how these actions will impact the livelihoods of low-
income populations, especially in developing and emerging market economies. Inclusive financial 
services, innovative financing models, and technologies will play an important role to support 
these economies in i) climate adaptation practices and making them more resilient to the effects 
of climate change, for example through better housing structures, ii) sustaining ecosystems 
through smart farming practices, which also supports the lowering of carbon emissions, and iii) 
transitioning to lower-carbon or cleaner energy consumption solutions, such as for example, 
rooftop solar solutions for micro and small businesses. 7  
 
9.  The shift towards a green economy is estimated to require around $1 trillion of investments 
annually and could yield direct economic gains of $26 trillion by 2030. Research has shown 
women entrepreneurs are more likely to start businesses with a sustainable focus, however, 
WMSMEs  face  significantly  larger  challenges,  compared  to  men,  in  accessing  finance  or 
affordable goods and assets8, limiting women’s social participation and chances for upward 
mobility. WMSMEs are more likely to cite access to finance as a major or severe constraint.   
 
6  World Bank Group, SME Finance Forum, IFC. 2017. MSME Finance Gap 2017. Washington D.C.  
https://www.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/03522e90-a13d-4a02-87cd-9ee9a297b311/121264-WP-PUBLIC-
MSMEReportFINAL.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CVID=m5SwAQA   
7  CGAP. 2021. Inclusive Finance Can Help the World Achieve COP26 Goals – Here’s How. Blog 
https://www.cgap.org/blog/inclusive-finance-can-help-world-achieve-cop26-goals-heres-how 
8  2x Climate Finance Taskforce Sector Notes: Investing in Financial Services 2021,

3 
According to Global Findex (2017)9, only 8.5% of women in Asia borrowed from an informal or 
formal source to start, operate, or expand a farm or a business, compared to 11% of men.  
 
10.  Furthermore, women in developing or emerging countries are often disproportionately 
affected by climate change. For example, women are more reliant than men on natural resources 
that may be adversely impacted by climate change. For instance, in Asia, rural women are 
primarily responsible for collecting water for their families. As climate change makes access to 
water less reliable, they will need to walk farther every day, limiting the time they have to engage 
in other tasks, including alternative income generation activities.10 Women’s improved access to 
finance not only can facilitate larger developmental impact, but women-owned and women-led 
businesses can play a key role in driving the green economy transition. At the same time, the 
Paris Agreement of 2015 targeting to limit global warming to below 2°C (compared to pre-
industrial levels), also emphasized that climate action needs to respect, and promote gender 
equality. 
 
11.  ADB has recently elevated its ambition to deliver climate financing to its developing 
member countries (DMCs) to $100 billion from 2019–2030. Expanded targets will also increase 
climate finance in ADB’s private sector operations and create more commercially viable projects 
for both ADB and private investors, improve new technologies and innovations in climate financing, 
and open up new areas of business for private sector climate operations.11 This is aligned with 
Strategy 2030, in which ADB is committed to have at least 75% of its operations by number of 
projects to feature climate adaptation and mitigation initiatives.  
 
12.  Hence, it is imperative that an additional work stream on green finance is included in the 
WFX activities going forward. In line with the core activities of WFX, it will continue to i) support 
financial institutions, especially in “greening their portfolios” or making better informed  credit 
decisions including green and gender considerations, ii) pilot innovative financing solutions with 
a green and gender focus, iii) identify innovative technology solutions promoting green and gender 
business practices, and iv) contribute to creating more awareness and knowledge sharing on 
ADB’s work supporting green finance and women. 
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
 
13.  The TA cluster has the following overall outcome: sustainable financial inclusion for 
women and women’s businesses increased and has defined outputs to be delivered by each of 
the  four  subprojects.  Subproject  4  will  specifically  contribute  to  the  TA  cluster  output  4: 
Maintenance of the WFX, including adding an addition output: Green finance and women, as an 
additional workstream.  
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
 
Output 1: Maintenance of the WFX. 
 
9  World Bank. Global Findex 2017.  
https://globalfindex.worldbank.org/#data_sec_focus 
Sample includes Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, China, Georgia, Indonesia, India, Kazakhstan, 
Kyrgyz Republic, Cambodia, Lao PDR, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Mongolia, Malaysia, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, 
Thailand, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Vietnam. 
10 UN Women Watch. 2009. Fact Sheet Women, Gender Equality and Climate Change 
https://www.un.org/womenwatch/feature/climate_change/downloads/Women_and_Climate_Change_Factsheet.pdf,  
11 ADB. 2021. ADB Raises 2019–2030 Climate Finance Ambition to $100 Billion. Manila, Philippines. 
https://www.adb.org/news/adb-raises-2019-2030-climate-finance-ambition-100-billion

4 
 
14.  As indicated and approved in subproject 1, to achieve the objective of an online interactive 
platform that is frequently used, requires a good understanding of the emerging issues in gender 
responsive financing, innovative technologies to digitize gender responsive financial services 
delivery or women’s businesses operating models and identification of other support needs of the 
target group (foremost FIs and women’s businesses). This entails moving to a more engaging 
approach which creates interaction between ADB and the target audience in DMCs. During and 
post COVID-19, it will also require a digital approach to interaction and engagement – including 
using social media channels such as LinkedIn, Facebook or Twitter, or online seminars for 
capacity building and support for cutting-edge technology.  
 
15.  During 2021, WFX collected feedback on preferences, trends and audience interests 
which further helped to shape WFX’s strategy but also made clear that a more agile interaction 
with the audience through an interactive website will be necessary. This website, hosted outside 
of adb.org, will be used to interact with different types of audiences, such as FIs, partner/sponsors 
and co-financiers. Feedback loops, including with DOC and ITD colleagues, have supported the 
final design of the WFX platform which will go live in Q1 2022. First partnerships with public and 
private sector stakeholders and linkages with other initiatives have been identified and are 
currently being finalized. One such partnership is with WeFi, the Women Entrepreneurs Finance 
Initiative, which is supporting activities in Viet Nam and the Pacific. 
 
16.  Going forward, output 1 will be the management and expansion of WFX, which includes 
activities aimed at creating a brand for WFX, promoting and publicizing ADB’s work on access to 
finance for women and women’s businesses and the platform’s content and activities, maintaining 
the online platform with interactive features for members, conducting pre-assessment/selection 
work on FIs to be supported, creating the community for stakeholders to share knowledge and 
experience, expanding the subscriber base and social media contacts, implementing social media 
marketing  campaigns,  preparing  and  designing  technical  assistance  activities  to  support 
increased lending through financial institutions,  and building partnerships with both technical as 
well as sponsoring and co-financing partners. To support ADB with these activities, resources will 
be contracted.  
 
Output 2: Green finance and Women.  
 
17.  While adapting business models to the “new normal” environment and operating more 
digitally and being gender-responsive is one challenge for FIs, another challenge is to respond to 
the increasing need to “green” their lending activities and also cease financing industries and 
sectors which have large carbon footprints and are exacerbating the effects of climate change. 
Growing awareness of climate change has led to an increase in the market sentiment amongst 
some private sector businesses and financial institutions in ADB’s DMCs that businesses need to 
become greener, which has been accompanied by certain regulatory actions to support this 
greening. For example, the EU sustainable finance disclosure regulations, introduced in March 
202112, required for the first time that funds provided information about the ESG risks in their 
portfolios, with the aim to strengthen ESG-compliant financing and improve market discipline 
around the green economy transition. This was followed by the Pan Asia Securities Lending 
 
12  KPMG. 2021. ESG financing – the future is now. 
 https://home.kpmg/uk/en/home/insights/2021/06/esg-financing-the-future-is-now.html

5 
Association creating policies using ESG principles for how to recall their shares for voting, and 
what collateral to accept.13   
 
18.  Introducing  new  digital  financial  services,  specifically  geared  to  enhance  gender 
responsive financing or applying a gender lens in the investment/credit and at the same time 
including  “green”  considerations  in  the  credit  or  portfolio  assessment  process  or  product 
development process will require different approaches and new skillsets for an FI.  Specifically, 
this  will  require  the  development,  piloting  and  implementation  of  innovative,  scalable,  and 
commercially viable financial risk management products that incentivize financial institutions to 
increase investments in climate change mitigation, adaptation, and disaster risk prevention with 
a focus on WMSMEs. WFX’s partner FIs will be supported through a range of activities, such as 
specific tailored expert advice, webinars or online toolkits, including green finance assessment 
tools  which  will  support  FIs’  efforts  to  ensure  a  greener  portfolio  as  well  as  risk  sharing 
components which will be developed along with innovative financing structures. FIs will receive 
the opportunity and support to pilot new technologies or financing structures and products before 
they can be scaled. 
 
19.   In the short-term, one such activity will be market research, including a mapping exercise 
of existing solutions, and a feasibility study to develop and pilot a green finance assessment tool.14 
ADB is already piloting a gender equality scorecard which enables an investor to evaluate a 
company’s actions to support gender equality against country and sector benchmarks. Lessons 
from this exercise will be useful for the green finance assessment tool, including consideration of 
the complementarity As a separate tool with both a gender15 and a green component, the WFX 
green finance assessment tool, will be piloted with one or two partner FIs to support integration 
of a green and gender lens in their credit assessments. The tool is expected to be pivotal to 
partner FIs on integrating green and gender components into their MSME business strategy to 
capture market opportunities and mitigating the risk by making the right credit and developmental 
impact decisions. 
 
20.  Additionally, WFX will support innovative financing structures, such as the issuance of 
bonds with a green and gender focus through engagements with FIs in target countries with the 
goal to deepen and expand capital markets in this space, as well as through capacity building 
with respect to the necessary legal and regulatory environments for expansion and deepening of 
the markets for green financial products with a gender focus.16 These activities will also be 
informed by lessons and knowledge from international green or sustainable finance initiatives.17 
WFX  aims  to  improve  WMSMEs’  access  to  finance  by  developing  financial  products  that 
specifically target WMSMEs supporting their efforts to create green business products and 
implement greener business practices. Risk sharing or mitigating components may be developed 
to support the completion of the structures. 
 
 
13  Reuters. 2021. Asset managers should set out ESG principles for securities lending 
https://www.reuters.com/business/sustainable-business/asset-managers-should-set-out-esg-principles-securities-   
lending-2021-05-27  
14 2x  Collaborative.  One  such  suggested  solution  is  the  Gender-Smart  Climate  Finance  Guide. 
https://www.2xcollaborative.org/2x-green-toolkit 
15   As aforementioned, if both tools could supplement or complement each other, this would be preferred and evaluated 
during the design and development of the green finance assessment tool.   
16   As OneADB, it is envisaged to collaborate with colleagues from other departments who are working either on climate 
change issues or with governments and regulatory bodies to create respective frameworks.  
17  For example, Green Finance Platform, https://www.greenfinanceplatform.org/themes/gender or the Gender-smart 
Investment Working group to which PSOD is a member.

6 
21.  WFX will also raise awareness and share knowledge through a range of webinars and 
publications, focusing on green finance and gender, with the twin-goals of developing WFX Green 
Finance as a credible platform as well as to educate and inform partner FIs and WMSMEs on 
green  finance  and  green  finance  products.  Related  to  this  WFX  will  continue  to  foster 
opportunities for creating a community by partnering with and sharing on initiatives with similar 
goals, such as for example gender-smart investment working group and the 2x Challenge. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
22.  Removed due to confidentiality. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
23.  ADB will administer Subproject 4 and its Private Sector Operations Department, Financial 
Institutions  Division,  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants  in  collaboration  with 
Transaction Support Division and Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, as 
necessary.

Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
Advance Contracting  Advance contracting will be considered for early recruitment purposes.  No 
contracts will be signed with consultants until subprojects have been 
approved.

7

24.  Consulting services. Individual consultants (national/international) will be recruited. A 
single-source selection may also be considered, subject to required approvals, should specific 
expertise be required.  Individual consultants will be recruited by PSOD/PSFI in accordance with 
the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. The estimated cost and requisite fields of 
expertise are indicative; and estimates will be finalized prior to approval of each TA subproject. 19 
20 Output based and/or lump-sum contracts will be considered but time-based contracts will be 
used, as appropriate.  
 
 
19  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20 As applicable, fixed out-of-pocket expenses, for administrative efficiency and to simplify the disbursement process 
will be used. No travel or other associated expenses are envisaged.
